newsitem.title: DUBAI: Gulf software piracy among world's highest -report.
newsitem.headline: Gulf software piracy among world's highest -report.

text.p: Piracy of computer software in Gulf Arab states is among the highest in the world, costing legitimate firms nearly $68 million in lost revenues in 1996, a trade watchdog body said on Thursday.

The Business Software Alliance (BSA), a watchdog body for the software industry, said in a statement that the piracy rate dropped by 16 percentage points in the United Arab Emirates to 72 percent in 1996 from 88 percent a year earlier.

But it quoted a report as saying Oman had a piracy rate of 95 percent -- the highest of the Middle East and Africa -- while Bahrain had 90 percent, Kuwait and Qatar 89 percent, and Saudi Arabia 79 percent.
"Levels of software piracy in the Middle East and Africa remain among the highest in the world with revenue losses estimates at $511 million in 1996," the statement said.
Estimated losses of revenue were $32.6 million in Saudi Arabia, $10.8 million in Kuwait, $8.7 million in the UAE, $7.9 million in Oman, $4.5 million in Bahrain and $3.2 million in Qatar, it said.
A BSA official said the figures, lower than those in earlier reports by the BSA, were reached using a new methodology.

"We believe the methodology used in preparing our new report is more scientific and gives more exact estimates of losses of revenue," Diane Smiroldo, vice president for public affairs, told Reuters by telephone from BSA headquarters in Washington.
The report was prepared by the BSA and the Software Publishers Association.

The UAE introduced copyright laws in 1992 as part of a bid to make it more attractive to foreign investors. The authorities have regularly raided shops and companies suspected of selling pirated goods.
